abstract: When Edward U. Gips was born at Women's Hospital on the Upper West Side, his father marked the happy event by sending a donation to a relatively new charity campaign conducted by The New York Times, called "The 100 Neediest Cases." That was in December of 1922.   Last month, Mr. Gips sent off two charitable contributions. As has been his unwavering practice, one went to the hospital, now part of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, and the other went to the campaign his father supported, now called The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
lead_paragraph: When Edward U. Gips was born at Women's Hospital on the Upper West Side, his father marked the happy event by sending a donation to a relatively new charity campaign conducted by The New York Times, called "The 100 Neediest Cases." That was in December of 1922.

lead_paragraph: A WHILE back, at a baby shower for a niece, I overheard the expectant mother being asked if she intended to return to work after the baby was born. The answer, which rocked me, was, "Yes, because I don't want to end up like Aunt Terry."

headline.print_headline: MODERN LOVE; Paradise Lost (Domestic Division)

abstract: Our hidden notes may have seemed banal, but to us they were a lifeline.
snippet: Our hidden notes may have seemed banal, but to us they were a lifeline.
lead_paragraph: The first note I ever wrote for my mother wasn’t very special, but she seemed to think it was. It said: “Hi Mom! Have a nice day! Love Skip!” (her nickname for me). My message was scribbled on a scrap of paper and tucked discreetly into her change purse. At the time I wrote it, I was 12. My mother worked as a key-punch operator — a profession now obsolete — at the Piscataway, N.J., offices of Phillips Van Heusen, the clothing company.

headline.main: A Final Message From My Mother
headline.print_headline: Message in a Change Purse

abstract: IT'S done: I've finally finished moving my ex-husband's belongings back into the large, cluttered farmhouse we used to share. He won't be coming back, but his shirts once again weigh down the closet rack, his boxes of household gadgets and financial files clog the attic and basement, and the furniture that wouldn't fit into the house now fills the third bay of the car barn.    Three years ago our marriage was ending. Corey and I had ''outgrown'' each other, shorthand for the malaise that had entered our marriage and despite our best efforts wouldn't leave. We were still friends; we didn't have big fights. All in all we'd had a pretty good marriage, and so we'd spent a lot of time discussing the necessity of divorcing.

abstract: Whether a simple pillow-and-mattress sanctuary from everyday stress or a lavish shrine to slumber, no necessity is more basic than a bed. And The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund recognizes that. When household possessions are destroyed in a fire or when a family simply counts more heads than it has pillows to lay them on, donations from the Neediest Cases Fund, now in its 85th annual appeal, can fill the void.  Articles, page 41.

abstract: Where certain things need to be done to make a cabin a home.

lead_paragraph: After years of renting rooms in other people’s houses and tiny apartments that we didn’t even bother to decorate, my wife and I finally purchased our first house: a cabin on a few acres in the woods of southern Tennessee. The structure itself was nondescript from the outside and spare on the interior, but the view of the pond out back was pretty, a peaceful expanse of calm water.

Many a stressed-out New Yorker would kill for the chance to unwind in an emerald paradise remote enough that a strange car passing up the road was a thrill, but I found myself floundering, unable to make peace with the fact that I was no longer a contributing member of society.

abstract: The editor of the series attempts to answer some of the prevalent questions about love he has observed Americans asking recently.
snippet: The editor of the series attempts to answer some of the prevalent questions about love he has observed Americans asking recently.
lead_paragraph: LOVE it or dread it, here we are again: Valentine’s Day. Why does such a holiday exist? One story is that back in the third century, a saint named Valentine, who faced execution for officiating illegal marriages, fell in love with his jailer’s daughter. Somehow he wrote and delivered a card to her that he signed, “From your Valentine.” Then he was killed.

headline.main: Explaining the Irrational: Here Goes ...
headline.print_headline: Explaining the Irrational: Here Goes ...

abstract: I was in the third grade when my family moved from Indianapolis in the early 80's and I became the lone black kid in a little Iowa town. At first there were stares, followed by the standard questions: Why did I call it getting a perm if it actually made my hair straighter? Did it hurt that my legs were so dry? Other kids who were different, who were fat or ugly or handicapped in some way, were ridiculed. But somehow I was special.    Special meant people were always nice to you. There were invitations to sit with the popular kids in the cafeteria and to attend the best slumber parties. Parents always addressed me by name, saying how delighted they were to have me in their homes.
snippet: I was in the third grade when my family moved from Indianapolis in the early 80's and I became the lone black kid in a little Iowa town. At first there were stares, followed by the standard questions: Why did I call it getting a perm if it actuall...

abstract: Not long ago, he followed her home from church and discovered where she had moved to escape his abuse. But he stopped at the corner, and Sonia K. believes he will not come any closer to her new apartment and the life she has begun there.   She was 13 when they emigrated from Belize together, leaving their families and childhoods behind. She loved him then, and said she would follow him anywhere. A year later, they had a baby daughter, and it seemed all the world was within their grasp.

lead_paragraph: WE have reached that recognizable wedding-reception moment when the D.J. queues up “Brown Eyed Girl,” the groom’s great-aunt grinds down to the floor in her silk pantsuit, and then needs a lift up. The caterers have replenished the empty steam trays with cheeseburger sliders, and the bridesmaids have removed their shoes. Anything could happen.

abstract: Photos of Dresden four years after end of World War II and at same sites 60 years later
snippet: Photos of Dresden four years after end of World War II and at same sites 60 years later
lead_paragraph: Four years after the end of World War II, Jochen Zimmermann took snapshots of his beloved hometown, Dresden, to preserve the devastation for the next generation. "He did these pictures with the same feeling that he photographed his family," says his son Harf. Last year, the younger Zimmermann retraced his father's footsteps to find out what had risen up out of the ashes of the Allied air raids, which took place 60 years ago today.

abstract: Liza Monroy article on her father, an Italian cook in Seattle, how he dropped out of her life when she was 17 and he became alcoholic, a happy meeting with him later in Genoa, where he may have gotten his life back in order and made promise, which he did not keep, to attend her wedding (M)
snippet: Liza Monroy article on her father, an Italian cook in Seattle, how he dropped out of her life when she was 17 and he became alcoholic, a happy meeting with him later in Genoa, where he may have gotten his life back in order and made promise, which...
lead_paragraph: When my fatherwas born, he was strapped to a board so his spine would grow straight. He claimed it was a common practice in rural Italy in the 40s. Thirty-six years later, my mother spotted a handsome man -- standing upright, working in a ship's kitchen. She was 24, traveling through Italy, vivacious and speaking the language fluently. They married after three months and moved in with her American Jewish family in Seattle. Italy was utopia to my mother, so she worked at its consulate. My father waited on tables.

That's my daughter, who's 6. She climbs onto the bed and presses her face next to mine.

He seemed like a quiet, polite, regular child — with curly hair and a shy smile, trying bravely to absorb the change in his life — and so he was, until he took off.

My hometown, Cali, spreads out below the Farallones mountains, which are beautiful to look at and just as beautiful to explore, an easy hike or ride in clean air away.

abstract: I give him bacon. I give him belly rubs. Is a little affection so much to ask?
snippet: I give him bacon. I give him belly rubs. Is a little affection so much to ask?
lead_paragraph: It was the movie “Hotel for Dogs” that sealed the deal. My kids had been asking for a dog for years, promising to take care of it, arguing how our family wouldn’t be complete until we had one. But after we rented that movie, in which humans can’t really find happiness without a canine pal, our kids became inconsolable in their dogless sorrow. Moaning, wailing — you’d have thought they severed an artery. Fine, we’ll get a dog. Yay, Dad!

abstract: A look inside high-level maneuvering for Persian flatbread.
snippet: A look inside high-level maneuvering for Persian flatbread.
lead_paragraph: In August, to be closer to my aging parents, my husband and I moved from Northern California to Orange County. My family settled there more than 30 years ago, not long after coming to the United States from Iran. I was 12, and the culture shock was pretty severe. There were moms in tennis skirts, dads in pastels, good-looking blond boys who surfed and good-looking blond girls who were born to wear bikinis. We were the only dark-haired people they’d ever met who didn’t speak Spanish. When I left for college, I told myself that I’d never live in such a homogeneous place again. Today the beaches are still beautiful and surfers still ride the waves, but the blonds are in the minority.

headline.main: The Real Supermarkets of Orange County
headline.print_headline: SUPERMARKET ZERANGI

abstract: The doctor’s diagnosis was multiple sclerosis. It was not fatal, he told the patient, “but your life will change tremendously.”
snippet: The doctor’s diagnosis was multiple sclerosis. It was not fatal, he told the patient, “but your life will change tremendously.”
lead_paragraph: Wonder Pearson knew something was wrong when her typing speed began to drop. She had averaged 95 words a minute while working as an administrative assistant at the Internal Revenue Service in Atlanta. But in fall 1995, not only did she get drastically slower, but she also found it hard to remember what others said in meetings while she took notes, and she struggled to keep her balance.

snippet: Lives column features photos of Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein and his family; photos were found in lavish home of his half-brother Watban Ibrahim al-Hassan after fall of Baghdad
lead_paragraph: The day after the fall of Baghdad, the photographer Bruno Stevens gained access to the lavish home of Saddam Hussein's half-brother Watban Ibrahim al-Hassan on the right bank of the Tigris River. Hundreds of family photographs were scattered on the floor of an upstairs corridor; others were tucked in a brown leather folder, emblazoned with an eagle, in one of the five bedrooms.

snippet: Amier Agha was beaten and his best friend executed by fighters in Syria. Intent on escaping the country, he persevered in the face of visa problems and President Trump’s travel ban.
lead_paragraph: Hope often came in subtle waves of clarity for Amier Agha. He would recall his younger brother’s new, prosperous life in San Francisco, which invariably made him think of images he had seen of sprawling metropolises and the New York City skyline. The thoughts filled him with warmth and wonder.

abstract: John Parodi Jr Lives column describes horror of Bali nightclub bombing by Al Qaeda and pain of losing his best friend to terrorism; drawing (M)
snippet: John Parodi Jr Lives column describes horror of Bali nightclub bombing by Al Qaeda and pain of losing his best friend to terrorism; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: There's a core group of us from Newport and Huntington Beach in California who are friends from way back. The first day in Bali we surfed at Uluwatu. I thought I was in surfing shape, but I hadn't surfed those kinds of waves in a year. Webby, that's what we called Steven Webster, was a great surfer. He wasn't as good as he thought he was, but still. After lunch, the surf was double overhead. The swell was building. As I paddled out, my arms cramped up. I could barely move and I thought, God, don't let there be a big set. One came but it swung away from me. I skirted getting injured that day or something worse.

headline.main: The Last Wave
headline.print_headline: LIVES; The Last Wave

abstract: After an arrest at 22, Donta James swore off dealing drugs but tried some of the crack cocaine he had peddled. He was hooked for more than 15 years.
snippet: After an arrest at 22, Donta James swore off dealing drugs but tried some of the crack cocaine he had peddled. He was hooked for more than 15 years.
lead_paragraph: It was not until after his arrest and decision to stop dealing drugs that Donta James became addicted to the very thing he had been peddling: crack cocaine.

headline.main: Getting Clean for His Son, From a Drug He Couldn’t Shake
headline.print_headline: Getting Clean for His Son, From a Drug He Sold and Couldn’t Shake

abstract: Seizing opportunity in a changing country, or at least giving it a try.
snippet: Seizing opportunity in a changing country, or at least giving it a try.
lead_paragraph: Last March, after dropping out of a doctoral program in Japan, I flew back to Kazakhstan, landing in the desolate airport of my hometown, Karaganda, a city of half a million. I would have to live with my parents again, and I was desperate for a job.

headline.main: An Interview in Kazakhstan
headline.print_headline: The Interview

abstract: After some rough high school years, Heydrick Padilla has put his math skills and passion for chemistry to use. But he needed financial assistance to get there.
snippet: After some rough high school years, Heydrick Padilla has put his math skills and passion for chemistry to use. But he needed financial assistance to get there.
lead_paragraph: Heydrick Padilla had always been a good student — particularly in math. He figured he would go to college and major in something like business that required numbers. Then he took a chemistry class.

headline.main: He Struggled at School, but Now Success Is Adding Up
headline.print_headline: He Struggled at School, but Success Is Finally Adding Up

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: LATELY I've become wary of the question ''Frank, what are you doing next Saturday night?'' In the month of May it can only mean one thing: I'm going to yet another prom. And no, I'm not doing a favor for a cousin. Cousins are out. I'm this century's new answer to the last-minute prom date: the gay best friend.    By the end of June I'll have worn the tuxedo I swiped from the school drama department three or four times. While most 18-year-old guys are preparing for their one big night, I'm whipping up more magical evenings than Lance Burton or David Copperfield.
snippet: LATELY I've become wary of the question ''Frank, what are you doing next Saturday night?'' In the month of May it can only mean one thing: I'm going to yet another prom. And no, I'm not doing a favor for a cousin. Cousins are out. I'm this century...
lead_paragraph: LATELY I've become wary of the question "Frank, what are you doing next Saturday night?" In the month of May it can only mean one thing: I'm going to yet another prom. And no, I'm not doing a favor for a cousin. Cousins are out. I'm this century's new answer to the last-minute prom date: the gay best friend.

headline.main: A Prince Charming for the Prom (Not Ever After, Though)
headline.print_headline: MODERN LOVE; A Prince Charming for the Prom (Not Ever After, Though)

abstract: Gladys Chen belongs to two New York City health clubs, New York Sports Club, which she visits only for her favorite toning-and-step class, and Clay, which she uses as extension of her apartment, checking her e-mail, eating and lounging; photo (M)
snippet: Gladys Chen belongs to two New York City health clubs, New York Sports Club, which she visits only for her favorite toning-and-step class, and Clay, which she uses as extension of her apartment, checking her e-mail, eating and lounging; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Gladys Chen belongs to two gyms, but not because she's an exercise fanatic. ''I see the gym as a way of extending my New York real estate,'' Chen, a 39-year-old campus recruiter for Banc of America Securities, says. ''It's a way of giving myself treats, without actually having to pay exorbitant prices -- which I can't afford anyway -- for a huge apartment.'' She takes a toning-and-step class at the New York Sports Club, a chain gym, but at least four times a week she heads to Clay, an upscale fitness club just off Union Square whose membership is limited to avoid crowding. ''There are never more than one or two people in the lounge,'' Chen says. ''You feel like you own the place.''

headline.main: Home Away From Home
headline.print_headline: LIVES; Home Away From Home

abstract: The city knew about Fausta Leon once.    Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other officials visited her. Thousands of New York newspaper readers, moved by her story, gave to a special fund that was set up for her and her family. Schoolchildren whom she had never met sent Ms. Leon handwritten cards offering their condolences.
lead_paragraph: The city knew about Fausta Leon once.

headline.main: Kindness Of Strangers After Death Of a Father
headline.print_headline: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Kindness Of Strangers After Death Of a Father

abstract: College students’ entries in this year’s Modern Love essay contest reveal a shift to technology-enabled emotional intimacy. Here is the winning essay.
snippet: College students’ entries in this year’s Modern Love essay contest reveal a shift to technology-enabled emotional intimacy. Here is the winning essay.
lead_paragraph: CURLED up at the foot of my bed, my face inches from the laptop screen, I stared anxiously at the Google chat box. “Will is typing,” the box told me, helpfully.

headline.main: Even in Real Life, There Were Screens Between Us
headline.print_headline: Even in Real Life, There Were Screens Between Us

abstract: A beautiful day in Maine, but outlooks can be deceiving.
snippet: A beautiful day in Maine, but outlooks can be deceiving.
lead_paragraph: The State of Maine, it’s often said, is a state of mind, a state sometimes inscrutable to relative newcomers like my husband, Marty, and me. So we were not surprised to be the only boaters heading out from the dock near Damariscotta on a gorgeous Saturday morning last November. We launched onto calm seas, so confident of the weather that we didn’t bother to check the forecast or pack our safety gear — the extra paddles, whistles, radio and flares. But half a mile from shore, we learned why no one else was out. The wind blew up, as did the chop. Our boats got skittish. Marty’s Red Sox cap blew off, and I begged him not to circle back for it. He assured me that we had seen much worse, that we would be fine. It was the response I had come to expect from him.

headline.main: Capsized
headline.print_headline: Capsized
